description: This course covers films, their formal and aesthetic features, and cultural contexts. Taught in English. This course will not fulfill the Language Other than English requirement of the Faculty of Arts. Course may be taken three times when topics vary. Prerequisite: consent of Department.

subject: GERM
title: Seminar in Culture
description: This course covers aspects of culture (art, language, environment, etc.) and their meaning and place in history and relationship to society. Taught in English. This course will not fulfill the Language Other than English requirement of the Faculty of Arts. Course may be taken three times when topics vary. Prerequisite: consent of Department.

subject: GERM
title: Special Topics
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department.

subject: GERM
title: Exercises in Translation: German into English

subject: GREEK
title: Beginners' Greek I
description: Elements of Classical Greek grammar and the reading of simple texts. Not open to students with credit in matriculation-level Greek.

subject: GREEK
title: Beginners' Greek II
description: A continuation of GREEK 101. Prerequisite: GREEK 101 or consent of Department.

subject: GREEK
title: Intermediate Greek I
description: Review of grammar, reading of Greek texts; translation of simple sentences from English into Greek. Prerequisite: GREEK 102 or consent of Department. Not open to students with credit in GREEK 301

subject: GREEK
title: Intermediate Greek II
description: Selections from Greek poetry and prose. Prerequisite: GREEK 201, 301 or consent of Department.

subject: GREEK
title: Fourth-Year Honors Tutorial
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department.

subject: GSJ
title: Directed Reading in Gender and Social Justice

subject: GSJ
title: Social Justice Workshop
description: Advanced study of theories of social justice. Students will complete 20 hours of Community Service-Learning (CSL) and reflect on how their CSL experiences were informed by or challenged the theoretical material explored in the course.

subject: GSJ
title: Gender Research Workshop
description: Advanced study of interdisciplinary research on gender and feminist scholarship.

subject: GSJ
title: Approaches to Gender and Social Justice Studies
description: An examination of interdisciplinary approaches to feminist scholarship with an emphasis on critical analysis and knowledge production for social justice.

subject: GSJ
title: Feminist Cultural Studies
description: Examines gender as a category of analysis in contemporary cultural theory in order to examine how gendered subjects are produced and regulated through everyday cultural practices.

subject: GSJ
title: Feminist Legal Studies
description: An advanced examination of feminist legal theories and strategies with an emphasis on the contemporary North American and British context. Topics will vary.

subject: GSJ
title: Feminist Theory Now
description: Examines current preoccupations within feminist theory. Topics and geographical focus will vary.

subject: GSJ
title: Feminist Historiography
description: Examines contemporary and historical approaches to writing feminist histories of a variety of regions and time periods.

subject: GSJ
title: Gender, Violence, and Social Justice in Africa
description: Critical examination of controversies around violence against African women based on insights gained from feminist debates, survivors' experiences of trauma, and studies by experts in the field.

subject: GSJ
title: Law and Feminism in Canada
description: A focus on the fundamentally contradictory role of law for women in Canada, building on the insights offered by feminist cross-disciplinary legal scholarship. (Not open to students with credit in WGS 420.)

subject: GSJ
title: Data, Power, Feminism
description: Examines the capacity of data to propose and produce social change. Not open to students with credit in DH 530 when topic is Data, Power, Feminism.

subject: GSJ
title: Feminism and Sexual Assault
description: Interdisciplinary consideration of conceptual, political, and legal strategies that feminists have deployed to confront sexual coercion with an emphasis on the contemporary North American context. (Not open to students with credit in WGS 431.)

subject: GSJ
title: Body Politics
description: An examination of contemporary theoretical approaches to bodies and embodiment, with particular emphasis on the ways that race, class, sexuality, gender, and (dis)ability shape bodily experiences. (Not open to students with credit in WGS 440.)

subject: GSJ
title: Transnational Feminism
description: This course engages in women's issues globally and across nations. Topics may include feminist theorizing, women's movements, development, human rights, reproductive politics and social governance.

subject: GSJ
title: Religion, Spirituality, and Social Justice
description: Ways in which adherents of world (Eastern and Western), Indigenous, and neo-pagan religious systems have advocated for social justice. Not open for students with credit in WGS 455.

subject: GSJ
title: Masculinities
description: This course surveys the status of masculinity and the emergence of contemporary masculinity studies within, alongside and, at times, against feminism and Women's Studies. (Not open to students with credit in WGS 460.)

subject: GSJ
title: Sexualities
description: Special Topics: This course offers advanced examination of selected issues in sexuality studies.

subject: GSJ
title: Indigenous Genders and Sexualities
description: Exploration of gender diversity and sexualities from Indigenous and Indigenous feminist worldviews, including critical examination of colonial constructions of gender and sexuality.

subject: GSJ
title: Special Topics - Topics in Gender and Social Justice Studies
description: Special topics will vary.

subject: GSJ
title: Special Topics in Feminist Theory
description: This course offers advanced study of selected issues in current feminist theorizing

subject: GSJ
title: Directed Research Project
description: Capping project.

subject: GSJ
title: Directed Research Project
description: Research activity equivalent to 3 units for registration status and fee assessment purpose.

subject: GSJ
title: Directed Research Project
description: Research activity equivalent to 6 units for registration status and fee assessment purpose.

subject: GSJ
title: Directed Research Project
description: Research activity equivalent to 9 units for registration status and fee assessment purpose.

subject: GTOTC
title: Dynamique du tourisme
description: L'étudiant acquiert des connaissances générales de base sur l'industrie du tourisme et ses différents secteurs pour en comprendre la dynamique. Il est en mesure de définir le phénomène du tourisme dans le monde ainsi que dans l'industrie du tourisme en Alberta et au Canada. L'étudiant identifie les tâches, opérations, normes, responsabilités et attitudes inhérentes à chacune des fonctions de travail dans le secteur touristique et compare les perspectives d'emploi. L'étudiant sera ainsi amené à établir des liens entre les besoins du marché du travail et les composantes du programme de Gestion touristique, à identifier ses aptitudes et ses intérêts et à se situer en regard des différents emplois accessibles au gestionnaire.

subject: GTOTC
title: Attraits naturels et activités
description: L'étudiant identifie les principales caractéristiques de la géographie humaine et physique de l'Alberta et ses composantes. Il se familiarise avec les contextes qui expliquent la présence des principales attractions naturelles et activités récréatives incontournables en Alberta. Il développe des méthodes de recherche et se familiarise avec les sources d'information qui lui permettront de situer, hiérarchiser et décrire les attraits naturels, la faune et la flore ainsi que les activités d'aventure dans les différentes régions touristiques de l'Alberta.

subject: GTOTC
title: Attraits patrimoniaux
description: L'étudiant s'initie aux grandes périodes de l'histoire de l'Alberta avant et depuis la création de la province. Il relie ces grandes périodes historiques aux composantes particulières du patrimoine archéologique, paysager, bâti, culturel, industriel et ferroviaire ainsi qu'à des sites classés au patrimoine mondial de l'Unesco. Il reconnaît les principales caractéristiques de l'architecture, de l'urbanisme et des paysages culturels de l'Alberta. Il décrit les principaux attraits patrimoniaux de l'Alberta en utilisant des sources d'information relatives à l'histoire et au patrimoine. Il présente les résultats d'une recherche sur l'occupation du territoire d'une région, ses attraits patrimoniaux, leur contexte historique et les liens avec l'histoire de l'Alberta.

subject: GTOTC
title: Outils technologiques du tourisme
description: Ce cours initie l'étudiant à l'éventail des outils technologiques pouvant servir à l'atteinte des objectifs de l'entreprise touristique. Il approfondit ses connaissances des systèmes informatiques, des dispositifs de mémoire, de stockage et des mesures de sécurité. L'étudiant utilise les logiciels, programmes, modèles et outils technologiques les mieux appropriés à chacune des tâches bureautiques. L'accent sera mis sur les programmes se rattachant aux opérations de l'entreprise, aux activités de promotion et à celles de communication des entreprises touristiques. Il se familiarise avec les technologies des médias au service du webmarketing ainsi qu'avec les logiciels de design graphique. Il actualise ses connaissances en évaluant et en qualifiant les meilleures pratiques et innovations technologiques servant l'industrie touristique.

subject: GTOTC
title: Cultures et authenticité
description: L'étudiant fait la distinction entre les principales dimensions d'une culture. Il identifie d'abord les principales ères culturelles et les éléments particuliers des grandes civilisations du monde. Puis, il s'initie plus spécifiquement aux caractéristiques de la culture albertaine. Il développe également sa compétence à comparer quelques caractéristiques de la culture albertaine à celles d'autres cultures. Finalement, l'étudiant identifie et présente les résultats d'une recherche sur une dimension culturelle albertaine ayant une incidence sur le tourisme.

subject: GTOTC
title: Région du monde
description: L'étudiant reconnait les contextes physiques, humains, économiques et culturels des principales destinations des Amériques et du monde. Il établit ainsi les paramètres d'une étude sur les principaux attraits touristiques d'une région du monde tout en la situant dans ses contextes géographiques, historiques et culturels. Il est également en mesure d'identifier et d'utiliser différentes sources d'information et de les analyser. Par la suite, l'étudiant est en mesure de caractériser et de présenter les principaux points d'intérêt des régions du monde.

subject: GTOTC
title: Guide touristique
description: Dans ce cours, l'étudiant se familiarise avec le métier de guide touristique et apprend à planifier le déroulement d'une visite guidée. Il y développe des techniques de communication et de prise de parole devant différents publics. Il utilise également les techniques d'interprétation nécessaires pour guider efficacement des groupes de visiteurs et leur faire vivre une expérience mémorable. Il développe les habiletés et méthodes de travail associées à l'accompagnement de groupe de touristes et au métier de guide-accompagnateur. Il apprend à résoudre les problèmes et à gérer les situations d'urgence propres à ses fonctions de travail.

subject: GTOTC
title: Conception d'expérience 1
description: L'étudiant participe à l'amélioration ou à la conception de produits, services ou activités touristiques. Il analyse d'abord des offres du marché et en évalue les forces et faiblesses ainsi que les atouts promotionnels du point de vue du consommateur et de l'avantage concurrentiel pour l'organisation. Il recherche des sources d'information fiables et développe son projet de conception d'expérience touristique en tenant compte des contingences logistiques.

subject: GTOTC
title: Conception d'expérience 2
description: L'étudiant progresse dans sa participation à l'amélioration ou à la conception de produits, services ou activités touristiques. Il met en application les concepts de marketing, communication, gestion, attraits naturels, cultures et outils technologiques acquis dans les cours précédents. Il utilise l'approche client et la notion de qualité continue dans tous les aspects de conception d'expérience touristique. Le développement de son projet se fait en tenant compte des attentes de la clientèle, des budgets, des exigences logistiques et légales ainsi que du principe de durabilité. Il s'agit ici d'une étude en profondeur des principaux éléments et approches favorisant la conception d'expérience touristique.

subject: GTOTC
title: Gestion d'évènements
description: Ce cours a pour but de comprendre la dynamique qui caractérise le secteur événementiel en Alberta et ailleurs. L'étudiant identifie les activités allant de l'organisation d'une réunion corporative à la gestion d'évènements à caractères internationaux. Il s'initie ainsi aux différents types d'évènements, leurs fonctions, leurs thématiques, leurs clientèles, leurs fréquences et leurs ampleurs. Il distingue les divers intervenants et reconnaît les facteurs clés au succès d'un évènement. Il analyse les outils de travail et de gestion et se familiarise avec l'élaboration de la planification complète d'un évènement incluant la logistique, l'administration et les communications. Il met en application ses connaissances en présentant l'élaboration de l'organisation d'un évènement.

subject: GTOTC
title: Gestion de l'hébergement touristique
description: Ce cours initie l'étudiant aux fonctions de la gestion de l'hébergement touristique. Il identifie les liens entre les principales opérations de l'hôtellerie telles que les réservations, la conciergerie, l'entretien ménager, la restauration, la réception et les activités de gestion et d'entretien général. Il se familiarise avec les systèmes de réservation et de transactions commerciales et identifie la terminologie spécifique à l'industrie hôtelière englobant divers types d'hébergement. Il assure la collaboration entre les services de l'entreprise et les divers intervenants présents dans la gestion de l'hébergement en tourisme. Il se renseigne sur l'application des lois et des règlements en hébergement touristique. Il applique ses connaissances dans la réalisation d'un travail concret adapté à l'industrie hôtelière. Finalement, il utilise l'approche client et la notion de qualité continue dans tous les aspects de la gestion de l'hébergement.

subject: GTOTC
title: Tourisme durable et qualité
description: L'étudiant apprend à différencier les types de certification associées à la qualité de service ou au développement durable du tourisme. Il planifie toutes les étapes nécessaires à l'implantation dans une entreprise d'une culture client dans un contexte de développement durable du tourisme. Il rédige une promesse et met en place des normes de service et des outils de mesure de la qualité. Il développe des habiletés à mobiliser une équipe dans un projet visant à intégrer la gestion de l'expérience client et les responsabilités éthiques de l'entreprise dans une démarche de qualité. Il développe les outils nécessaires pour accompagner (communiquer, superviser et suivre) le personnel dans la démarche et pour mesurer et reconnaître le progrès accompli.

subject: GTOTC
title: Tourisme culinaire et rural
description: L'étudiant se familiarise avec l'expérience culinaire en tourisme aussi bien qu'au tourisme en milieu rural. Le tourisme culinaire ou tourisme gourmand se pratique aussi bien dans un restaurant cinq étoiles d'une ville qu'à la ferme. Le tourisme rural, qu'il repose sur l'agrotourisme ou non, met l'accent sur l'offre touristique hors des grands centres urbains. L'étudiant évalue l'offre albertaine en destination culinaire et rural et la compare avec d'autres régions du monde. Il conçoit et prépare un travail de session représentant une dimension culinaire et/ou rural en tant qu'attrait touristique albertain.

subject: GTOTC
title: Stage en milieu de travail
description: Le stage se déroule pendant l'été de la première année du programme. Il donne aux étudiants l'occasion de mettre en application et de continuer à développer les connaissances et habiletés acquises pendant la première année de leur formation. Les étudiants effectuent leur stage dans des organismes ou entreprises offrant des services dans les domaines couverts par la formation. Il s'agit donc le plus souvent de stages de type « Service à la clientèle ». Parmi les objectifs formatifs du stage, notons l'interaction avec les touristes et les intervenants du secteur touristique et la mise en pratique des notions apprises pendant la première année du programme. De plus, l'étudiant évaluera son intérêt et goût personnel ainsi que les perspectives de carrière offertes par l'industrie.

subject: HADVC
title: Introduction to the History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture
description: Introduction to the history of art, design and visual culture.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in the 15th and 16th Century
description: History of art, design and visual culture in the 15th and 16th centuries, with a focus on the Italian Renaissance, covering global exchange, anatomical illustration, and the invention of the artist.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in 17th Century Europe
description: History of art, design and visual culture in the 17th century. Highlights the visual culture of Italy, Spain, France, the Netherlands and Flanders, covering representations of the body, politics, and identity in the work of artists such as Caravaggio, Rembrandt, Velázquez, and Rubens.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in 19th Century Europe
description: History of art, design, and visual culture in Europe during the 19th century, focusing on work produced during this socially and politically turbulent time. Includes discussion of Neoclassicism, Romanticism, Realism, Impressionism, and Symbolism.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in Early 20th Century Europe
description: History of art, design and visual culture in Europe from the early to mid-20th century. Focuses on modernist and avant-garde modes of art and design in their historical context. Includes discussion of Expressionism, Cubism, Surrealism, and more.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in the United States
description: History of art, design and visual culture in the United States from the Colonial period to World War II. Includes work created by and depicting women, Indigenous peoples, and ethnic minorities and addresses such issues as politics, religion, nature, and industry.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Modern Design in Europe and North America
description: This course explores how modern design in Europe and North America are shaped by global flows of knowledge, things, and people. The course focuses on decolonizing graphic design, industrial design, fashion design, architectural design, and urban planning.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Photography
description: History of photography, starting with its invention in the 19th century.

subject: HADVC
title: Special Topics in the History of Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in Latin America
description: Introduction to the historical study of art, design and visual culture in Latin America, including Mesoamerican, pre-Hispanic Andean, Colonial, and Post-Independence cultures.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in China
description: Introduction to the historical study of art, design, and visual culture in China from the neolithic era to modern times.

subject: HADVC
title: China Art Now
description: Chinese cultural identity as expressed in local and global economies of art, design, and visual culture from the Maoist era to the present.

subject: HADVC
title: China's Design Revolution
description: Students will study the historical foundations, theory, and practice of sustainable design in China in response to our global environmental crisis.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in Japan
description: Introduction to the historical study of art, design, and visual culture in Japan. Includes painting, sculpture, architecture, gardens, decorative arts, and prints, and addresses such concerns as identity, nation, tradition, and modernity.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in the Contemporary Era
description: Introduction to key issues in art, design, and visual culture from the mid-20th century to the present, including art and identity, performance and politics, social sculpture, institutional critique, new media, bio art, relational aesthetics, social practice, and the pedagogical turn.

subject: HADVC
title: History of Art, Design, and Visual Culture in Canada
description: This course covers issues related to land, region, war, and cultural institutions in Canada. Key examples of contemporary art will be used to introduce these histories with a particular focus on art from First Nations, Métis, and Inuit visual culture, leading to discussions of political identity, colonization, and settler colonial relations.

subject: HADVC
title: Geographies of Art, Design, and Visual Culture
description: The history of art, design and visual culture of a particular geographic location (e.g. nation, city, region, continent). Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Modernism and Modernity
description: Aspects of the modern as it applies to the artistic practices of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Design Theory and History
description: Historical and/or contemporary issues in design practice and theory. Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Issues in the History of Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: China Urban: Art & Design Now
description: The historical and contemporary Chinese city-as representation, model, catalyst, and socio-political construct. Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Art and Institutions
description: The relationship between objects and their modes of interpretation, circulation and display (e.g. museums, academies, exhibitions, etc.) Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Introduction to Performance Art
description: Introduction to performance art of the 20th and 21st centuries. Prerequisite: Any 6 units in HADVC 2XX with a minimum grade of B- in each course, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Theory and Methods in Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Topics in Early Modern Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Topics in Art, Design and Visual Culture in the Early 20th Century
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Topics in the History of Design
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Special Topics in the History of Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Topics in Asian Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Topics in Art, Design and Visual Culture from the Mid-20th Century to the Present
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary. Prerequisite: Any HADVC 3XX with a minimum grade of B, or consent of the Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Studies in Early Modern Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Studies in Art, Design and Visual Culture in the Early 20th Century
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Studies in the History of Design
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Special Topics in Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Studies in Asian Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Studies in Art, Design and Visual Culture from the Mid-20th Century to the Present
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Advanced Theory and Methods in Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department.

subject: HADVC
title: Special Topics in Art History
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

subject: HADVC
title: Directed Research Project
description: Students enrolled in this capstone for the course-based MA program work independently with a supervisor to develop a research topic of their choosing.

subject: HEBR
title: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew I
description: Fundamentals of Biblical Hebrew for reading and translation purposes. Not open to students with previous knowledge of Biblical Hebrew or credit in HEBR 201.

subject: HEBR
title: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew II
description: A continuation of HEBR 210. Prerequisite: HEBR 210 or consent of Instructor. Note: Not open to students with knowledge of Biblical Hebrew that exceeds one semester of university study.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Principles and Practice in Human Ecology
description: An introductory course that provides a foundation in the body of knowledge that constitutes the field of human ecology (i.e., its history and philosophy; theories for studying everyday life). The scope of the field is explored and skills that foster effective professional practice by human ecologists are discussed.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Textiles
description: An introductory exploration of the origin, creation and use of textiles in our world. Chemical and physical properties of fibres and fabrics are introduced and an understanding of how these properties influence various clothing and textile end uses is developed.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Material Culture
description: The study of a range of objects and environments (from clothing to buildings) within selected time periods, and the study of particular perspectives through which such items can be interpreted. Students explore and learn about the connections between personal, social, temporal, and cultural contexts and the objects and environments that contribute to these contexts.

subject: HECOL
title: Intimate Relationships
description: A consideration of the sociological, psychological, and personal factors affecting the development, maintenance and dissolution of intimate relationships today.

subject: HECOL
title: Human Sexuality
description: An inquiry into the nature of sexual behavior, its personal and cultural sources, and the personal, familial and societal implications.

subject: HECOL
title: Seniors and Their Environments
description: An introduction to the environments in which older people live. The course uses an ecological framework to study the symbolic, physical, interpersonal, community, and political environments of older adults in Canada and other world regions.

subject: HECOL
title: Fashion Industries
description: An introduction to the soft goods industry including an overview of the apparel sector, apparel production, channels of distribution, fashion oriented products, global competitive influences, and career opportunities.

subject: HECOL
title: Design Studies and Practices
description: Explores the production of designed things as material culture from a human ecological perspective. Theories and practices of object production focus on design processes including visualization, communication, inspiration/influence, and interface in the context of two-and three-dimensional design. Students learn theories during lectures and apply these in hands-on design projects in the studio.

subject: HECOL
title: Apparel Design and Construction Fundamentals
description: In this studio course students develop fundamental awareness and skills for the textiles and clothing field including machine operation, design and construction terminology, pattern manipulation and fit, and quality construction techniques. Students construct samples and garments with a focus on professional standards in problem solving and production. Prerequisites: One of HECOL 250, 170, or DES 135 or DES 138/139.

subject: HECOL
title: Survey of Historic Dress in the Western World
description: Introduction to the historical development of dress in the Western World with contemporary applications in design, merchandising, arts performance, education and museums. Resources include the Anne Lambert Clothing and Textiles Collection.

subject: HECOL
title: Applications of Textile Science
description: Advancement of textile concepts introduced in HECOL 170 with an emphasis on textile finishing, colouration, care and maintenance. Techniques for fibre identification and yarn and fabric structural analysis are covered. Prerequisite: HECOL 170.

subject: HECOL
title: Policy Development and Evaluation
description: Processes of policy development, implementation and analysis; Canadian policy environments, institutional frameworks and instruments; application to professional practice and to current social and economic issues.

subject: HECOL
title: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Theories and processes of program planning, implementation, and evaluation from a human ecological perspective. Prerequisite: successful completion of 60 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Dynamics
description: An introduction to family dynamics from the perspective of family theory. Changes in family dynamics across the life course will be examined using theoretical concepts, research, and practical application of concepts. Prerequisite: successful completion of 60 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Interviewing and Counseling
description: An introduction to interviewing and counseling strategies for working with individuals using a strengths-based, human ecological approach. Prerequisite: 30 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Family Finance
description: An introduction to the principles of money management for individuals, households, and families. Students learn basic financial literacy skills and tools required to make key financial decisions by identifying financial goals, assessing current resources, developing and implementing a financial plan and evaluating financial progress. It is also expected that students will be able to apply these tools in their professional work to enhance clients' financial literacy and their ability to resolve financial management challenges. Prerequisite: ECON 101; it is recommended that students have completed both ECON 101 and 102.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Economic Issues
description: An examination of current issues affecting the economic well-being of Canadian families and of government policies which address those issues. Issues explored include work and family; the economics of childbearing, education, delayed life transitions, and aging; intrafamily allocation of resources; and money and family relationships. Prerequisites: ECON 101; it is recommended that students have completed both ECON 101 and 102.

subject: HECOL
title: Cross-Cultural Textiles
description: An introduction to the historical and technological development of cross-cultural textiles and survey of common textile-making techniques, designs, and embellishments. Ethnographic textiles are analyzed in the context of socio-cultural, political, economic, environmental, and aesthetical meanings. The course combines lectures, class discussions, videos, and examination of artifacts from the Clothing and Textiles Collection. Prerequisite: 30 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Apparel Design and Product Development I
description: Principles of design and merchandising applied to apparel design and portfolio development. A creative problem-solving approach to production of a line of clothing. Prerequisite: HECOL 254. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Dress and Culture
description: The complex phenomenon of bodily adornment is explored in relationship to values, attitudes, activities, beliefs, and forms of knowledge. Clothing is considered in terms of how it is expressive of various aspects of culture. Students develop analytical skills to help them understand the role played by clothing in different times, places, and contexts. Prerequisite: HECOL 268. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Fashion History: Interpretations & Exhibition
description: Advanced study of Western dress from the 18th century to the present. Lectures and labs introduce students to artifactual research and the handling, storage, examination, documentation and exhibition of artifacts. Sources explored include artwork, fashion plates, texts, caricatures, photography, patterns, reproduction garments and historical clothing from the Anne Lambert Clothing and Textiles Collection. Students co-curate an exhibition as part of the course. Prerequisite: HECOL 268. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Quality Assurance for Textiles and Apparel
description: Exploration of quality assurance of textiles and apparel through materials testing. Performance of textiles relative to product standards and specifications. Prerequisite: HECOL 270.

subject: HECOL
title: Environmental Sustainability in Textiles
description: Examination of the clothing and textiles industry and the environmental impact of textile production and consumption. Topics may include but are not limited to, circular economy, life-cycle thinking, environmental labelling, sustainable fibres, sustainable fabric and finishing technologies, consumption patterns and post-consumer use. Prerequisite: HECOL 170 and 60 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Intentional Professional Practice
description: Preparation for human ecology practicum placement. Effective workplace relationships and issues involved in professional practice are explored within the context of being a practicum student. Reflective practice and career development are key concepts of the course. Prerequisite: HECOL 100 and 90 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Practicum in Human Ecology
description: Supervised field experience. Students are placed in professional settings appropriate to their academic background and career goals. Participation in a weekly online seminar is required. Prerequisite: HECOL 408. Requires payment of additional student instructional support fees. Refer to the Tuition and Fees page in the University Regulations section of the Calendar.

subject: HECOL
title: Parent-Child Relationships
description: An exploration of parent-child relationships, with a concentration from infancy through adolescence. An examination of theoretical and research perspectives of parent-child relationships and the practical application of those perspectives. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 310. Prerequisite: PSYCH 223.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Challenges
description: An in-depth exploration of several family challenges (e.g. addiction, homelessness, and childhood and adult abuse). An introduction to specific prevention and intervention approaches related to family challenges. Prerequisite: HECOL 313.

subject: HECOL
title: Working With Families
description: Assessment and counseling strategies for working with families using a strengths-based, family-centred approach. Prerequisite: HECOL 315 or EDPY 442.

subject: HECOL
title: Families and Aging
description: Current issues in mid- and later-life families including relationships between aging parents and adult children, grandparent relationships, family caregiving. Prerequisite: HECOL 214 or HECOL 313.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Policy Issues
description: Analysis of current policy issues faced by Canadian families and the examination of policies and programs affecting family well-being and relationships. Prerequisite: 60 units or consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Textiles and Apparel in the Global Economy
description: Production and distribution of textiles and apparel in a global context; issues and policy related to international trade agreements; impact of national and international consumer, labor and environmental standards. Prerequisite: HECOL 241.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Law
description: Family law regulates intimate and domestic relationships. Examines from a user's perspective, how statutory and common law affects family relationship issues such as marriage and divorce, child custody and child welfare, adoption, and new reproductive technologies. Normally offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: HECOL 300.

subject: HECOL
title: Apparel Design and Product Development II
description: Advanced problems in apparel design and product development. Draping and fabric manipulation techniques are explored. The focus is traditional specialty fabric techniques and experimental production methods. Prerequisite: HECOL 254. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Fashion and Material Culture: Politics, Economies, Societies, c. 1600-1900
description: Examines the evolution and practice of fashion as a social, economic, political and cultural phenomenon from a cross-cultural perspective. Prerequisite: consent of instructor. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Research Methods for Material Culture and Design Studies
description: Explores how to do research into the relationships between people and objects (from clothing to buildings). Students will learn how to conduct primary research through a range of methods, approaches, and theories associated with material culture and design studies. Prerequisite: 60 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Material Culture in Practice
description: Explores how human ecological and material culture approaches contribute to the analysis of a range of contemporary issues in design practice. Prerequisite: 60 units.

subject: HECOL
title: Advanced Materials for Protective Clothing
description: Students explore advanced materials for protective clothing. Resistance of textiles to mechanical, thermal, chemical, biological, and electrical hazards as well as questions of durability and comfort are discussed with an emphasis on current research. The course describes phenomena and mechanisms involved, presents appropriate materials and structures, and depicts the relevant test methods. Prerequisite: HECOL 370 or consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Environmental Sustainability in Textiles
description: Examination of the clothing and textiles industry and the environmental impact of textile production and consumption. Topics may include but are not limited to, circular economy, life-cycle thinking, environmental labelling, sustainable fibres, sustainable fabric and finishing technologies, consumption patterns and post-consumer use. Prerequisite: HECOL 170 and 60 units. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 372.

subject: HECOL
title: Clothing and Materials for Sport and Safety
description: A human ecological exploration of the selection, use and performance of clothing and materials used for workplace safety protection and sporting/recreational activities. Prerequisite: HECOL 370. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Nanotechnologies and Smart Textiles
description: Students explore opportunities offered by nanotechnologies and smart materials/structures as they relate to textile products. Mechanisms involved, materials used, fabrication processes, properties/performance obtained, and some examples of commercial applications are presented. Challenges encountered with these new technologies are also discussed. Prerequisite: HECOL 170 and 60 units; or consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Textile Analysis and Care
description: Deterioration and preservation of modern and historical textiles are investigated. Macro and microscopic evidence are combined with theories of fibre degradation and textile soiling to identify the causes of wear, discoloration and failure during the normal use, care and storage of textiles. Theory related to the cleaning of textiles will include detergency, bleaching, dry-cleaning and specialized procedures for historical textiles. Prerequisite: HECOL 270. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Independent Investigation in Human Ecology
description: Independent project or study of a topic in human ecology planned by the student with an instructor. Open to human ecology students only. Prerequisite: successful completion of 75 units, application to Department, and consent of Instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Selected Topics in Family Ecology
description: Normally offered in Spring or Summer. Can be taken for credit more than once if the topics are different. Prerequisite: successful completion of 60 units or consent of Instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Selected Topics in Textiles and Clothing
description: Normally offered in Spring or Summer. Can be taken for credit more than once if the topics are different. Prerequisite: successful completion of 60 units or consent of Instructor. Requires payment of additional student instructional support fees.  Refer to the Tuition and Fees page in the University Regulations section of the Calendar.

subject: HECOL
title: Independent Project in Human Ecology
description: Independent study of a topic in human ecology planned by the student in consultation with the Instructor. Independent studies may be taken more than once for credit.

subject: HECOL
title: Graduate Intentional Professional Practice
description: Preparation for human ecology practicum placement. Effective workplace relationships and issues involved in professional practice are explored within the context of being a practicum student. Reflective practice and career development are key concepts of the course. Prerequisite: consent of the instructor. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 408.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Structural Equation Modeling
description: Provides an introduction to the theory and practice of structural equation modeling with social science data. Practical application in Mplus is emphasized by computing and interpreting statistical models within this framework, including path analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, and structural equation modeling. Prerequisites: Statistics coursework covering regression analysis. Normally offered in alternate years.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Health and Wellness; Theoretical and  Measurement Issues for Research and Practice
description: Critical examination of the conceptualization and measurement of family health and the interrelationships between the health of families and their members. Applications to research and practice in a variety of disciplines including family ecology, nursing, health promotion, occupational therapy, education, and psychology. Not to be taken if credit received in NURS 532.

subject: HECOL
title: Selected Topics in Human Ecology
description: Topics of current interest. May be taken for credit more than once. Prerequisite: consent of Instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Material Culture and Design Studies: Methods of Qualitative Analysis
description: Explores specific qualitative research approaches, theories, and methods that relate to the fields of material culture and design studies. Students collect, examine, and interpret data concerning people's relationships with items of material culture (including design). Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 465.

subject: HECOL
title: Material Culture in Practice
description: Explores how human ecological and material culture approaches contribute to the analysis of a range of contemporary issues in design practice. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 469.

subject: HECOL
title: Advanced Materials for Protective Clothing
description: Students explore advanced materials for protective clothing. Resistance of textiles to mechanical, thermal, chemical, biological, and electrical hazards as well as questions of durability and comfort are discussed with an emphasis on current research. The course describes phenomena and mechanisms involved, presents appropriate materials and structures, and depicts the relevant test methods. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 470.

subject: HECOL
title: Review of Literature in Clothing, Textiles and Material Culture Studies
description: Review of scholarly literature related to clothing and textiles sciences and/or material culture research. A literature review is a required part of this course. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 680.

subject: HECOL
title: Clothing and Materials for Sport and Safety
description: A human ecological exploration of the selection, use and performance of clothing and materials used for workplace safety protection and sporting/recreational activities. Prerequisite: consent of instructor. Normally offered in alternate years. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 473.

subject: HECOL
title: Introduction to Nanotechnologies and Smart Textiles
description: Students explore opportunities offered by nanotechnologies and smart materials/structures as they relate to textile products. Mechanisms involved, materials used, fabrication processes, properties/performance obtained, and some examples of commercial applications are presented. Challenges encountered with these new technologies are also discussed. Prerequisite: consent of the instructor. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 474.

subject: HECOL
title: Fundamentals of Human Comfort in Protective Clothing
description: Examination of heat and mass transfer between clothing and the human body in relation to comfort and protection.

subject: HECOL
title: Textile Analysis and Care
description: Deterioration and preservation of modern and historical textiles are investigated. Macro and microscopic evidence are combined with theories of fibre degradation and textile soiling to identify the causes of wear, discoloration and failure during the normal use, care and storage of textiles. Theory related to the cleaning of textiles will include detergency, bleaching, dry-cleaning and specialized procedures for historical textiles. Prerequisite: consent of instructor. Normally offered in alternate years. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 476.

subject: HECOL
title: Research Methods in Textile and Apparel Science
description: An examination of qualitative and quantitative research methods relevant to clothing and textiles scholarship.

subject: HECOL
title: Ways of Knowing in Human Ecology
description: Enquiry into the nature, scope and object of human ecology knowledge; the distinct contributions of various modes of inquiry; and the relationship between ways of knowing and selected issues related to the acquisition of knowledge, such as ethics and research methods.

subject: HECOL
title: Fundamentals of Aging
description: A critical analysis of the issues and environments that influence the lives of older Canadians. Focus  is on theories and knowledge about age-related normative and non-normative changes and their interaction with the physical, social, community and policy environments of older adults.

subject: HECOL
title: Review of Issues and Trends in Family Ecology and Practice
description: Content and philosophy of the study of the family from a human ecological perspective.

subject: HECOL
title: Theory in Family Ecology
description: Consideration of family theory as it relates to research and practice. Pre or corequisite: HECOL 610 or consent of Instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Challenges
description: An in-depth exploration of several family challenges (e.g., addiction and homelessness). An introduction to specific intervention approaches related to family challenges. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 412.

subject: HECOL
title: Graduate Practicum in Human Ecology
description: Selected practicum placements to integrate theory and practice in a variety of agencies. When used as the capping exercise for the course-based Master's program, requirements include a written report and an oral presentation to the Department and/or where appropriate to relevant agency staff. Prerequisites: consent of Supervisor and Department.

subject: HECOL
title: Families and Aging
description: Current issues in mid- and later-life families including relationships between aging parents and adult children, grandparent relationships, family caregiving. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 415.

subject: HECOL
title: Intimate Relationships
description: In-depth examination of intimate relationships, including theoretical perspectives, research methods, relationship forms and processes, and how context affects relationships. Students will consider how sociological, psychological, and personal factors affect the development, maintenance and dissolution of intimate relationships today.

subject: HECOL
title: Work-Family Integration
description: An examination of the complex relationship between two important social institutions: work and family. Topics include demographic, social, and economic changes that have shaped the work-family relationship as a contemporary issue; its implications for individuals, families, work environments and society; and theoretical and practical perspectives on the challenges of and strategies for managing the relationship.

subject: HECOL
title: Family Policy Issues
description: An examination of the elements of policies and policy issues that affect contemporary Canadian families. The elements of policies and policy issues studied include: their origins and underlying ideologies; their institutional frameworks and foundations; and their substance, nature, and impact on families. Prerequisite: HECOL 300 or consent of instructor. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 440.

subject: HECOL
title: Research Project in Human Ecology
description: An original research project, conducted with guidance from a faculty member, typically resulting in the preparation of a research report and a submission to a professional academic conference for a poster or paper presentation OR the preparation of a manuscript that is submitted to a scholarly journal for publication. May be taken more than once for credit.

subject: HECOL
title: Perspectives on Material Culture and Design Studies
description: A critical analysis of specific issues, theories, and perspectives that influence material culture and design studies, as fields of research and practice. This course looks into designed things, from clothing to urban environments, and is focused on supporting students as they explore issues and develop theories connected to their research.

subject: HECOL
title: Themes in Material Culture and Design Studies
description: An overview of disciplinary themes and approaches to theory and research as they relate to the interdisciplinary fields of material culture and design studies. This course raises issues that are relevant to the study of diverse objects and creative practices, from art to engineering.

subject: HECOL
title: Fashion and Material Culture: Politics, Economies, Societies, c. 1600-1900
description: Examines the evolution and practice of fashion as a social, economic, political and cultural phenomenon from a cross-cultural perspective. Prerequisite: consent of the instructor. Not to be taken if credit received for HECOL 464.

subject: HECOL
title: Material Culture and Curatorship
description: Examines the different ways in which artifacts-from the body to the built environment-are interpreted in physical and virtual exhibitions. The course is designed to include a variety of student interests but pieces from the Anne Lambert Clothing and Textiles Collection will serve as preferred artifacts for assignments. Guest lecturers and site visits add to lectures on museum practices such as handling and mounting, storage, registrarial processes, research and exhibition design. Students co-curate an exhibition as part of the course.

subject: HECOL
title: Topics in Family Science and Aging
description: Topics of current interest in Family Science and Aging. May be taken for credit more than once. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Topics in Material Culture
description: Topics of current interest in Material Culture studies. May be taken for credit more than once. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Topics in Textiles and Clothing
description: Topics of current interest in Textiles and Clothing. May be taken for credit more than once. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

subject: HECOL
title: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Theories, approaches, and processes fundamental to the development, implementation, and evaluation of programs that effect change and build capacity in families, communities and organizations.

subject: HECOL
title: Professional Seminar 1
description: This professional development seminar is one in a series that provides an introduction to graduate study in the Department of Human Ecology, and to career development and professional issues in human ecology. Includes topics such as the field of human ecology, what it means to be a graduate student, and student-supervisor relationship. Typically taken in the first year of the graduate program.

subject: HECOL
title: Professional Seminar 2
description: This professional development seminar is one in a series that focuses on career development and professional issues in human ecology. Includes topics such as writing for academic and non-academic audiences and research ethics. Typically taken in the first year of the graduate program.

subject: HECOL
title: Professional Seminar 3
description: This professional development seminar is one in a series that focuses on career development and professional issues in human ecology. Includes topics such as the process of the doctoral program and comprehensive and candidacy exams. Typically taken in the second year of the doctoral program.

subject: HECOL
title: Professional Seminar 4
description: This professional development seminar is one in a series that focuses on career development and professional issues in human ecology. Includes topics such as funding agencies and preparing grant proposals, non-academic careers for PhDs, and post-doctoral fellowships. Typically taken in the second year of the doctoral program.

subject: HECOL
title: Directed Research Project
description: Comprises the capping exercise for the course-based Masters programs. Requirements include conducting an applied research project, and both a written project report and an oral presentation to the Department, and where appropriate, to relevant practising professionals.

subject: HGEO
title: Introduction to Human Geography and Planning
description: The spatial organization of human landscapes, and significance of the distribution of human activity. Not available to students with credit in HGP 100.

subject: HGEO
title: Cities and Urbanism
description: Introduction to urban geography and planning emphasizing interactions between the built environment and processes of social and economic change. Topics include urban form, housing and diversity in North American cities. Prerequisite: Any 3 unit course. Not available to students with credit in HGP 240.

subject: HGEO
title: Sustainable Development and Environmental Management
description: An introduction to sustainable development approaches to dealing with environmental issues. Prerequisite: Any 3 unit course. Not available for students with credit in HGP 250 or SUST 201.

subject: HGEO
title: Human Dimensions of Environmental Hazards
description: Interactions between environmental hazards, individuals and communities; risk reduction strategies by members of the public and management agencies. Prerequisite: Any 3 unit course. Not available to students with credit in HGP 252.

subject: HGEO
title: Social and Cultural Geography
description: Connections between space, society and culture at multiple scales. Formation and significance of cultural landscapes, and shaping of social life by spatial arrangements. Prerequisites: HGP 100 or HGEO 100, and HGEO 240 or HGP 240. Not available for students with credit in HGP 341.

subject: HGEO
title: The Spatial Economy
description: Introduction to the study of the location, distribution and spatial organization of economic activities on both the local and the international scale. Prerequisites: HGEO 100 or HGP 100 and any HGEO 2XX or PLAN 2XX course. Not available for students with credit in HGP 342.

subject: HGEO
title: Geographies of Health and Health Care
description: Geographic research on health and health care, including environmental, social, individual and institutional factors. Prerequisites: HGEO 100 or HGP 100 and any HGP 2XX, HGEO 2XXor PLAN 2XX course. Not available for students with credit in HGP 343.

subject: HGEO
title: Topics In Human Geography
description: Theory and application of contemporary issues in human geography. Prerequisite: HGP 100 or HGEO 100. Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated.

subject: HGEO
title: Topics in Regional Geography
description: Selected regions are studied in a regional or topical format. Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated.

subject: HGEO
title: Research Methods in Human Geography
description: Collection and analysis of data for social research in human geography. Research design and sampling procedures. Both qualitative and quantitative methods are explored. Fieldwork required. Prerequisites: HGEO 100 or HGP 100 and any HGEO 2XX, PLAN 2XX, or HGP 2XX course. Not available for students with credit in HGP 399.

subject: HGEO
title: Environment and Health
description: An examination of relations between human health and environmental issues, particularly those related to the natural, built, and social environments. Prerequisite: HGEO 343, HGP 343 or consent of Instructor. Not available for students with credit in HGP 443.

subject: HGEO
title: Resource Management and Environmental Policy
description: Roles of governmental and nongovernmental organizations, industry and private enterprise, and advocacy organizations in addressing issues of resource scarcity and environmental policy. Institutions, policies, and strategies for resource and environmental management at the provincial/state, national, and international levels. Prerequisites: HGEO 250 or HGP 250. Not available for students with credit in HGP 450.

subject: HGEO
title: Human Dimensions of Environmental Change
description: Examination of the human dimensions of climate change. Topics include climate change politics, public perceptions and impacts, vulnerability and resilience, mitigation and adaptation. Prerequisite: Any 300-level EAS, HGP or HGEO course or Consent of Instructor. Not available for students with credit in HGP 452.

subject: HGEO
title: Geographical Information Systems for Social Science
description: The application of spatial analytic tools to social science topics. Assignments impart technical aspects through hands-on experience with commercial and in-house spatial analysis software. Prerequisite: EAS 221. Not available for students with credit in HGP 470 or PLAN 470.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Topics in Human Geography
description: Prerequisites: HGEO 100 or HGP 100, and any one HGEO 2XX or HGP 2XX course. Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated.

subject: HGEO
title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Required for Honors students in their final year. Restricted to honors students in Human Geography. Prerequisites: Any 300 level HGP or HGEO course and approval of the Department.

subject: HGEO
title: Directed Study in Human Geography or Planning I
description: Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor. May be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated.

subject: HGEO
title: Human Geography Field School
description: Intensive field or practical study in Human Geography, typically as part of a team working off-campus. Details and areas of study may vary from year to year; consult the department about current offerings, fees and timing. Prerequisites: Any HGEO 2XX, HGP 2XX or PLAN 2XX course plus consent of Instructor. Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated. This course may require the payment of additional fees. Refer to the Tuition and Fees page in the University Regulations section of the Calendar.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Environment and Health
description: An examination of relations between human health and environmental issues, particularly those related to the natural, built, and social environments. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor. Research project. Classes concurrent with HGEO 443. Not available to students with credit in EAS 494, 594 or HGEO 443.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Resource Management and Environmental Policy
description: Roles of governmental and nongovernmental organizations, industry and private enterprise, and advocacy organizations in addressing issues of resource scarcity and environmental policy. Institutions, policies, and strategies for resource and environmental management at the provincial/state, national, and international levels. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor. Not available to students with credit in HGEO 450 or HGP 450.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Human Dimensions of Global Change
description: Examination of the human dimensions of climate change. Topics include climate change politics, public perceptions and impacts, vulnerability and resilience, mitigation and adaptation. Not available to students with credit in HGEO 452 or HGP 452.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Geographical Information Systems for Social Science
description: Provides spatial analytic tools to social geographers and provides a social science perspective to geoprocessing students. Examples arise from marketing, operations research, sociology, and urban and economic geography. Assignments impart technical aspects through hands-on experience with commercial and in-house spatial analysis software. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor. Not available to students with credit in HGEO 470 or HGP 470.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Issues in Human Geography
description: Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated. Classes concurrent with HGP 481.

subject: HGEO
title: Advanced Human Geography Field School
description: Intensive field or practical study in Human Geography, typically as part of a team working off-campus. Details and areas of study may vary from year to year; consult the department about current offerings, fees and timing. Topics vary; may be taken more than once for credit provided no topic is repeated. This course may require the payment of additional fees. Refer to the Tuition and Fees page in the University Regulations section of the Calendar.

subject: HINDI
title: Beginners' Hindi I
description: Introduction to Hindi language and culture. Note: not to be taken by students with native or near native proficiency or any previous instruction in Hindi.

subject: HINDI
title: Beginners' Hindi II
description: Continuation of HINDI 111. Prerequisite: HINDI 111 or consent of the Department. Note: not to be taken by students with native or near native proficiency. Students who have not taken HINDI 111 but have some background in Hindi will be tested the first days of class for eligibility.

subject: HIST
title: The Atomic Age: The World After 1945
description: Introduction to key economic, political, and societal changes at the global scale.

subject: HIST
title: The Pre-Modern World
description: World history from the end of the 6th century to the 15th century.

subject: HIST
title: The Early Modern World
description: World history from the 15th century through the 18th century.

subject: HIST
title: The Modern World
description: The world since the beginning of the 19th century. Not open to students with credit in HIST 120.

subject: HIST
title: The History of the World in the Last 10 Years
description: Global historical developments over the last 10 years with emphasis on the interaction of states and peoples.

subject: HIST
title: Technology and History
description: The role of technology in historical developments around the world.

subject: HIST
title: The Emergence of the Atlantic World
description: The history and legacies of the transatlantic slave trade that linked Europe, Africa, and the Americas, emphasizing economic, political, social and cultural ramifications.

subject: HIST
title: Plague: Disease and Epidemics in History
description: The causes, impacts, and experiences of disease in human history.

subject: HIST
title: History of Sexuality in the Americas
description: History of sexual behaviour, identities, and regulations in the Western Hemisphere from the colonial era through the twentieth century.

subject: HIST
title: Drugs in Modern Global History
description: The social, cultural, and political histories of criminalized drugs like opium, marijuana, amphetamines, and cocaine.

subject: HIST
title: War, Revolution, and Society
description: The causes, course, and consequences of major conflicts around the globe, including their wider social effects.

subject: HIST
title: Democracy, War and Consumer Capitalism: The Making of Modern Europe
description: European history from the Enlightenment to the present.

subject: HIST
title: Global History of Alchemy: Quests for Gold, Power, and Immortality
description: Theories and practices of ancient and medieval alchemy in its historical and cultural contexts.

subject: HIST
title: Origins of Ancient India: Cities, Migrations and Peoples
description: Introduction to the formative period of South Asian history, from approximately 3000 BCE to 600 CE, covering the Harappan civilization, Indo-European migration, and the first kingdoms of the Ganges valley.

subject: HIST
title: Sex Work and Intimate Labour in Global History

subject: HIST
title: Video Games, History, and Storytelling
description: The use of world history in video games.

subject: HIST
title: Warfare Since 1789: From Mass Armies to Thermonuclear War

subject: HIST
title: History of Computing
description: Survey of the history of computers, computing, and human/computer interactions.

subject: HIST
title: Capitalism
description: The development of global capitalism through an exploration of historical changes in trade, markets, ideas, work, consumption, and government policies.

subject: HIST
title: From Constantine to the Cathedral: Europe in the Middle Ages
description: A survey of Europe from the fourth to the thirteenth century.

subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of European history from approximately 1200 to 1800.

subject: HIST
title: Famine as Genocide in the 20th Century: The Case of the Holodomor
description: Exploration of the 1932-33 famine in Ukraine in the context of other 20th century famines, genocide, survivor experience, and Soviet history.

subject: HIST
title: The Making of the Modern Middle East
description: Twentieth-century political and cultural history, following the Ottoman Empire's disintegration

subject: HIST
title: The Pacific World Since 1500
description: Exploration, migration, trade, and geopolitics in the Pacific region, connecting Australia and the Pacific Islands with Asia and coastal North and South America.

subject: HIST
title: Colonial Latin America
description: Survey of Latin American history to 1810.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Latin America
description: Survey of Latin American history since 1810.

subject: HIST
title: The Golden Age of Islam: History of the Muslim World to the 16th Century
description: Historical overview of the rise of Islam in seventh century Arabia and the political, economic and cultural impact of subsequent expansion into Asia, Africa and Europe.

subject: HIST
title: Africa from Medieval to Modern Times
description: African history to the 19th century.

subject: HIST
title: Africa in the 20th and 21st Centuries: From Colonial Rule to Modern Nations
description: African history since the 19th century.

subject: HIST
title: American History to 1865
description: Survey of United States history from colonial times to the Civil War.

subject: HIST
title: From the End of Slavery to the Present: American History Since 1865
description: Survey of United States history from the Civil War to the present.

subject: HIST
title: Slavery in the Americas
description: Comparative examination of slavery in the Western Hemisphere from its creation to abolition.

subject: HIST
title: Religion in History
description: A study of a religious tradition(s), its teachings and rituals, along with its function in a specific historical setting, including its role in conditioning and reflecting a particular society and culture.

subject: HIST
title: East Asia to 1500
description: Survey of history of East Asia (China, Korea, Japan, Vietnam) to 1500.

subject: HIST
title: East Asia from 1500
description: Survey of the history of East Asia (China, Korea, Japan, Vietnam) from 1500 to the present.

subject: HIST
title: China and the West
description: A survey of Chinese-Western cultural interactions from the time of Marco Polo to the present.

subject: HIST
title: Classical India to 500 CE
description: The world of Classical India, from the emergence of the Mauryan Empire in the fourth century BCE to the close of the Gupta Empire in the fifth century CE.

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to History as a Discipline
description: Introduction to the basic concepts of historical inquiry and techniques of research and writing in History. Course includes lectures and discussions. Required for History majors. Prerequisite: A previous course in History or consent of the Department.

subject: HIST
title: World War One
description: The European conflict and its global dimensions, with an emphasis on political, social, and cultural histories.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval India from 500 to 1500 CE
description: A survey of the history of India from the close of the Gupta and Vakataka kingdoms in the fifth century CE to the decline of the Delhi Sultanate and the Vijayanagara Empire in the sixteenth century CE.

subject: HIST
title: History of Science, Technology and Medicine: Key Moments
description: Pivotal events in the history of science, technology, and medicine using a wide variety of historical sources, such as photographs, artifacts, films, letters, and diaries.

subject: HIST
title: An Introduction to the History of Sciences, Technology, and Medicine
description: Broad survey of topics in the history of science, technology, and medicine.

subject: HIST
title: 20th-Century Warfare
description: In-depth look at some of the conflicts of the 20th century, the course examines wars and revolutions including the two world wars, the Korean and Vietnam wars, African guerrilla wars, and the Gulf War. Analyze the causes and consequences of war and the evolution of weaponry. To be offered in alternate years.

subject: HIST
title: World War Two
description: The global conflict, with emphasis on political, social, scientific, and cultural aspects.

subject: HIST
title: The History of Christianity
description: Lecture and discussion course about the development of Christian traditions in the world.

subject: HIST
title: State and Society in Mughal India
description: A political and social history of India from the 16th-19th centuries, focusing on the Mughal empire.

subject: HIST
title: Gandhi, Resistance, and Non-violence
description: Introduction to the history and legacy of Mahatma Gandhi. Topics may include Gandhi's influence on India's national freedom movement from colonial rule, his application of non-violence as a method of resistance, and the ways in which his religious worldview shaped his ideology and actions.

subject: HIST
title: Europe in the Age of Total War, 1890-1945
description: European experience with total war, economic crisis, cultural change and totalitarian regimes in the new era of mass politics and Great Power conflict.

subject: HIST
title: Germany in the 20th Century and Beyond
description: The economic, social, cultural, and political histories of the various Germanies in their European and global contexts, from 1900 to the present.

subject: HIST
title: Saints and Medieval Christianity
description: Beginning with the early Christian background, this course treats the various forms of sanctity (martyrs, monks and clerics) that appeared in medieval Europe, along with the social functions that the cult of the saints fulfilled in the world of Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages.

subject: HIST
title: Sexuality and Gender in Modern Europe
description: Introduction to the social organization, cultural construction, and political dimensions of sexuality and gender in Europe from the eighteenth to the twenty-first centuries.

subject: HIST
title: The History of Paris
description: Introduction to the history of Paris from late antiquity to the present day, drawing on film, music, art, philosophy, geography, architecture, and literature.

subject: HIST
title: A History of the Habsburg Monarchy, 1526-1918
description: The multinational empire of the Habsburgs from the unification of Austria, Bohemia and Hungary to the destruction of the empire in World War I.

subject: HIST
title: History of Vienna
description: Introduction to the history of Vienna from prehistoric times to the present day, drawing on film, music, art, geography, architecture, and literature.

subject: HIST
title: Foundations of East European History
description: The ethnic, religious, social, and political factors which shaped the development of the peoples of Eastern Europe from the Middle Ages through the Age of Enlightenment. Intended as background to the later histories of the Balkans, 'Central Europe', and Ukraine.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval and Early Imperial Russia
description: Russia from Kievan Rus' through Catherine the Great's reign, 900s to 1800. Note: Not open to students with credit in HIST 318.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Global History
description: Addresses historical processes or themes affecting diverse areas of the world. Can be repeated if course content varies.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Ukraine
description: Ukrainian history from the late eighteenth century to the present. Note: Not open to students with credit in HIST 315, 316, or 317.

subject: HIST
title: Russia from Reform to Revolution, 1800-1917
description: Reaction, reform, and revolution, from Paul I to Nicholas II. Note: Not open to students with credit in HIST 318.

subject: HIST
title: Russia in the 20th Century
description: An historical survey of domestic and foreign policy, from Nicholas II to Yeltsin.

subject: HIST
title: The Middle East in the Making: 1300-1920
description: The rise and demise of the Ottoman Empire. An overview of the religious, cultural and political making of current-day North Africa, Near and Middle East, and Eastern Mediterranean. HIST 111 and 112 are recommended but not required.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in History at the Movies
description: Provides students with the historical tools to analyze history as it is presented in movies. Topics will vary according to the instructor(s).

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Indigenous History
description: Addresses select themes in the histories of Indigenous peoples. Can be repeated if course content varies.

subject: HIST
title: The Modern British Empire and the Commonwealth Experience

subject: HIST
title: Global Environmental History
description: Histories of interactions between non-human nature and diverse cultures, with attention to inequality and environmental change.

subject: HIST
title: Slavery and Abolition in Africa
description: Explores slave trading out of Africa, domestic slavery within it, and European policies that were used to justify conquering and colonizing the continent. Course materials may include primary documents and images, slave narratives, historical fiction, and videos.

subject: HIST
title: History of Women in the United States
description: A multicultural and multiracial history of women from the colonial period to the present.

subject: HIST
title: African American History from Slavery to Black Power
description: The African American experience in the United States from the colonial era to the present.

subject: HIST
title: History of American Medicine
description: The social history of American health care and health practitioners. How sickness, health, and healing have changed over the course of American history.

subject: HIST
title: Canadian Environmental History
description: Brings the natural environment onto a shared stage with social, economic, political and cultural history in Canada from the last ice age to the present.

subject: HIST
title: History of Alberta
description: Economic, social, and political realities that underlie the many images of Alberta.

subject: HIST
title: The Canadian West to 1885
description: Native diplomacy and warfare, the development of fur trade societies, and European colonization to the suppression of the North-West Rebellion.

subject: HIST
title: The Canadian West Since 1885
